## Unlevered Beta and CAPM (Using Business Risk Only) A firm has **levered beta = 1.43**, **D/E = 0.65**, **tax rate = 30**%. What is its **unlevered (asset) beta**? (Use the standard formula removing leverage.) ::: {.question-block}
✅ **Why this is the answer:** Unlevered beta measures **business risk only** (no financial leverage). We “strip out” leverage using: βU = βL / [1 + (1 – T) × (D/E)]. This lets us compare firms **on operating risk**, independent of capital structure. **Your numbers:** βU = 1.43 / [1 + (1 − 0.3) × 0.65] = **0.98**.
::: If the **risk-free rate** is **3**% and the **expected market return** is **9**%, what is the **expected return using CAPM with the unlevered beta**? ::: {.question-block}
✅ **CAPM intuition:** Investors require compensation for time value (**Rf**) and for bearing market risk (**β × MRP**). We use the **unlevered beta** to price the **business risk** without leverage: E[R] = Rf + βU × (Rm − Rf) = **8.9%**. This gives a **baseline cost of equity** for the project/asset **before** financing effects.
:::
